headline.seo: Clinton Is Noticeably Absent From Latest Health Care Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: The Great Society lives. While everyone is talking about Medicare, Lynda Bird Johnson Robb is stepping up to remind everyone that it was her father, former President Lyndon B. Johnson, who signed Medicare into law in the first place. Ms. Robb appears in a video released Tuesday on behalf of the Alliance for Retired Americans and its campaign to mobilize older Americans to support an overhaul of the health care system. In the video, Ms. Robb says she is distressed to see Medicare being maligned in the current debate and urges older Americans to help push for health insurance for everyone.
docs.abstract: Alliance for Retired Americans releases video featuring Lynda Bird Johnson Robb, in which she offers reminder that it was her father, former President Lyndon B Johnson, who signed Medicare into law; video is part of group's campaign to mobilize older Americans to support overhaul of health care system; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Great Society lives. While everyone is talking about Medicare, Lynda Bird Johnson Robb is stepping up to remind everyone that it was her father, former President Lyndon B. Johnson, who signed Medicare into law in the first place.     Ms. Robb...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama may not have much trouble convincing the nearly 160 million people who receive health insurance through their employers that the system needs to be fixed, if a new survey of employer health benefits is any indication. The average cost of a family policy now exceeds $13,000 a year, having doubled over the last decade, according a survey released Tuesday by the Kaiser Family Foundation.
docs.abstract: Survey of employer health benefits released by Kaiser Family Foundation shows that average cost of family insurance policy now exceeds $13,000 yearly, having doubled over last decade; predicts that similar increases over next decade will translate to aveage policy for family costing roughly $24,000 per year; charts (M)
docs.snippet: President Obama may not have much trouble convincing the nearly 160 million people who receive health insurance through their employers that the system needs to be fixed, if a new survey of employer health benefits is any indication.      The average...

docs.lead_paragraph: Although the White House has signaled that a so-called public option may not be integral to a health care overhaul, some interest groups are trying to pressure Democrats to keep the idea of a government-run insurance plan on the table. Health Care for America Now, a coalition of more than 1,000 labor unions and advocacy groups, rolled out a $1.2 million advertising campaign on Tuesday, urging passage of a public option and demonizing the health insurance industry, which opposes the idea.
docs.abstract: Advocacy group Health Care for America Now rolls out $1.2 million advertising campaign urging passage of public option and demonizing health insurance industry for opposing government reform plan (M)
docs.snippet: Although the White House has signaled that a so-called public option may not be integral to a health care overhaul, some interest groups are trying to pressure Democrats to keep the idea of a government-run insurance plan on the table.     Health...

docs.lead_paragraph: The House voted, 240-179 and largely along party lines, to publicly rebuke Representative Joe Wilson, Republican of South Carolina, for his brief outburst of "You Lie!" against President Obama during the address before a joint session of Congress. The Democratic leadership pushed for the formal resolution expressing disapproval of his conduct, while Republicans -- within and outside the House --denounced the vote as a partisan action.
docs.abstract: The House voted largely along party lines, 240-179, to admonish Representative Joe Wilson for shouting at President Obama.
docs.snippet: The House voted largely along party lines, 240-179, to admonish Representative Joe Wilson for shouting at President Obama.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even though the White House has signaled that a so-called public option may not be necessary for a health care overhaul, some interest groups are trying to pressure Democrats to keep it in play.

headline.main: Labor Groups Begin Ad Campaign for Public Option

docs.abstract: A coalition of labor unions and advocacy groups has begun a nationwide television ad campaign for the public option -- and against insurance companies.
docs.snippet: A coalition of labor unions and advocacy groups has begun a nationwide television ad campaign for the public option -- and against insurance companies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, a liberal from West Virginia, became the first Democrat in the Senate to say he opposes the health care proposal that Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Finance Committee, has been drafting in negotiations with two other Democrats and three Republicans.

headline.main: Senator Rockefeller, a Key Democrat, Says He Opposes Baucus Plan

docs.abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, a liberal from West Virginia, became the first Democrat in the Senate to say he opposes the health care plan proposed by Senator Max Baucus.
docs.snippet: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, a liberal from West Virginia, became the first Democrat in the Senate to say he opposes the health care plan proposed by Senator Max Baucus.
